												KoH is an excellent medieval RTS, very underrated and unknown by many players. It was originally released in Belgium 2004 by Sunflowers and then by Paradox for North America in 2005. The developers could have done some extra things to spice it up more, such as more historical units, random events like disease, fires, barbarian/mongol invasion, the plague, a royal family tree, etc. I find it a little odd that knights live forever unless killed in battle or by a spy, and your Kings only die of old age or in battle or by a spy. Didn't the developers know people died of disease and other things in those days, just like we do in today's world? I'm not trying to flame, not at all, the game is great, but a little more realism would have made KoH the best RTS ever. All in all, and despite my personal thoughts, KOH is a great game that everyone should try.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												Knights of Honor, while certainly not unique from the dozens of other Paradox published or produced map based games, Appeals to me as the most accessible for new time players, while still easily one of the more fun ones for more advanced gamers. Its core gameplay was easy for me to understand with 25 minutes, and I had mastered many of the simple tasks by the end of an hour, allowing me to start bigger and better parts of the game.  The game is laid out similar to Total war, where you control a country during a time of war and unrest (In this case, during the medieval ages). The game is largely map based, and while it has RTS type battles, I recommend leaving it to the AI auto battle system, as that is a lot less frustrating and tedious.  The games highlights for me are based around its well balanced uses of espionage, religion, economy, military and diplomacy. Any of these may be used to achieve total victory, or a unique combination of them. This allows the player to choose their play style, unlike Total war, where you are trapped in a looping cycle of battle.  Like all games, KoH has its share of problems, and a few of them are major. On some machines, the highest available resolution is 800 X 600, which looks very odd on modern monitors. Un-skippable start up logos that last around 1 minute each time is annoying and makes launching the game a pain. Actual in game issues are few in the area of glitches, but some sections of the game are cruelly tedious, like rebellion and currency inflation. While it may be open for debate if these ruin the game, it definitely adds another dimension to the gameplay.  While KoH may not be on the same level of polish as other map – based strategy games, it should not be forgotten, especially for the bargain price of $9.99.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												This is basically a prettier and less complicated version of the Europa Universalis games. The mechanisms are more transparent compared to that series, and the game feels more limited, less open-ended. This can be both a good and a bad thing, depending on your preferences.Trade plays a relatively important role, because you have to have access to trade goods in order to gain kingdom advantages, and you probably can't produce all of these trade goods yourself unless you conquer a lot of territories.Military and combat are straightforward. Waging extensive wars is complicated by two factors: one, you can only have a limited number of armies at any time; and two, rebels regularly appear in recently conquered territories, so you have to garrison some of your armies in the new territories for a rather long time to defeat the rebels.The limit on the number of armies is due to a clever idea that I don't remember having seen in any other similar strategy game: You have a set number of slots to which nobles from your kingdom can be assigned, and you also assign a specific role to each noble. One such role is the general (marshal), which is important because every army must be led by one. Second, a noble can be assigned the trader role; traders are sent to other kingdoms either to earn money or to gain access to goods that you don't produce yourself. Third, there is the cleric who can convert your provinces to your state religion. And fourth, a noble can serve as a spy either to intercept other spies sent by foreign powers or to be sent to other powers by you in order to gather information and carry out covert attacks.Having played through one game, it is obvious that Knights of Honor is far too easy on default settings. I played as the kingdom of Hungary and was able to conquer the whole eastern half of Europe and part of Anatolia during the rule of my first 6 kings or so (which seems the only way to measure time in this game, since the current calendar year is not shown anywhere as far as I can tell). Given the fact that Hungary was at best an intermediate regional power during this time span and most definitely did not have the resources to carry out such conquests, it is safe to say that you can forget about Knights of Honor if you want to play something that resembles a historical simulation. (For example, when I tried to pull the same stunt in EU III, I was duly wiped out by the Turkish.)The winning conditions are a point that is more problematic than historical accuracy (which is not really that important for a game). One way to win the game is to collect all of the kingdom advantages. This is easy to achieve, you basically have to have access to 5 sea ports and money, both of which are easy to come by. The second way is to be elected the emperor of Europe, for which it is necessary to have the support of the five most powerful kingdoms. This seems rather difficult to achieve. Being the most powerful kingdom yourself is easy, but to get the support of the others you would also have to have perfect relations with them. This wouldn't be that difficult per se either, since everybody else is more than happy to ally themselves with you if you are the most powerful kingdom. However, if you are already allied with one power, this excludes an alliance with powers that are enemies of your ally. So not only is it necessary for you to be on good terms with other kindoms, you should also guarantee that your friends are friends with each other as well. This is quite impossible to achieve given the mechanisms provided by Knights of Honor.Logically, diplomacy should be the way to do this, but the diplomacy system in this game is quite useless. You can only ask your allies to attack some other kingdom, but there is no option available to ask (or order) them to make peace with one another and leave each other alone, or else. This, of course, is not surprising but rather seems to be the norm in these games, but it is still a completely stupid omission that basically renders the whole diplomacy system completely useless.Beside the fact that the emperor victory condition is unrealistically and artificially difficult to achieve, another major problem with the game is the AI. They don't seem to be interested in the victory conditions. Coastal powers should presumably have it easy to attain the kingdom advantages victory, since all they need for that is ports, but apparently no AI power does that. As for the emperor condition, in the emperor elections no kingdom ever got any votes, which suggests that the AI isn't even trying to win that sort of victory. The AI also tends to do stupid things. For example, tiny, one-territory kingdoms constantly declare war on my kingdom, being by far the most powerful empire in Europe, with the explanation that they need land. It apparently does not occur to them that they should rather try to expand toward their similarly tiny neighbors, which might not destroy them instantly.To sum it up, Knights of Honor is a rather one-sided affair. You either win a trade victory relatively early on, or you try to win the diplomatic victory, which takes unreasonably long, and the computer players do not really represent any serious challenge to this. The only thing they are somewhat good at is the military challenge, which is especially present in the early game. Later on you become so powerful that even this part becomes too easy.Despite these serious problems, I'll give Knights of Honor a recommendation since there are good ideas in it, and the early game is relatively good. The fact that the late game becomes very unbalanced is rather annoying, but this is unfortunately the case for lots of strategy games (even otherwise ingenious games like the Civilization series).

Recommendation level:|-|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|▓▓▓▓▓▓|░░░░░░|+|Knights of Honor is a medieval strategy game which mixes the style of the Total War and Europe Universalis series with real-time elements. It is almost ten years old now, but is still a competent game in its genre.Pros:Nice mix of kingdom management and military strategy. Provinces can be taken over, developed and defended when needed. Military units can be moved with marshals through the map in real-time. Leveling and perks are deep enough. Fights can be simulated or played on one of the many pre-built battlefields. Sieges and engagements need strategic decisions. Diplomacy is important, every move influences the way how others will act. The whole map of Europe can be seized and dominated. Many nations can be controlled in three different period. The world feels living due to the many events occurring constantly. Pre-rendered graphics look decent even in 2014 and the menus are also usable.Cons:Only two game modes available, campaign and battle. Multiplayer campaign would add to value. Some features are too simplistic and leave some more to be desired, like the importance and use of trade and exotic goods. The limitation of knights/nobles available for actions are frustrating, especially when a bigger kingdom is governed. The way military units transported and used in slots and their numbers feel less appropriate at cases. Also, units moving on the battlefield can collide with each other causing well set formations to break. AI sometimes prefer annoying and dumb decisions both in diplomacy, map movement and battles and can be exploited at times. Graphics engine lacks options demanded nowadays, like higher resolutions and widescreen.Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a complex military strategy game with many ways and choices available. The game features long campaigns with dozens of played hours and also has a high replay value.MY OPINION: 8.0/10 (GREAT)Graphics: 7/10World Design: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Sound: 7/10Replay Value: 9/10

												I've been playing Knights of Honor for many years. A popular comparison would be to say this is a real time version of Medieval 2: Total War. However, there are a lot more nations and quite a bit of options. I was delighted to see this game was on steam ever since I broke the original CD I got back around 2004 or 2005. This game is very deep with a lot to discover, but not a lot of information about what is available. For instance, if you are in the Early period, you can take control of Normandy and try to recreate the Norman conquest. Once you eliminate all English nations, a popup will appear with an option to change your name to England and get a bonus, or stay as Normandy. Also, in the (I think Late) medieval period, you can control a Spanish nation and attempt to reunite Spain. One thing to note, there are cheat codes for this game, and there once was a very robust and active community who developed some fantastic mods. There used to be challenges for who could conquer England the fastest, beat the game with Kingdom Advantages, total conquest, etc. It's sad that this community is all but gone now since it added a lot of life and variety of the game. This game has a huge learning curve, but once you get it, it's fairly straight forward. Develop your own strategies for running your kingdoms, building your castles, raising your armies, and conquering the world. I recommend this to any strategy lover or medieval fan.

												I didn't think I would like this game, it looks a bit like the kingdoms of a childrens story and sounds like it's narrated by Morgan freeman. But you can get use to the art design and the gameplay is actually what I was looking for.             If you thought "Total War" has been missing the mark recntly with grand strategy as I have, then this game is perfect for you. Sure you're not going to have much in the way of Epic battles but the strategy part is there. Both the campaign map and battles are in Real Time, and there is not time pausing as far as I can tell. The game requires you to think on your feet, busy marching your armies north? well you just missed the enemy swing around and invaded you from the east.             This game also simulates one thing "Total War" does not; Campaigning. For instance if you want to take the fight in enemy territory you have to plan, you only get a base 100 food in your cart (Can be upgraded with buildings or leader abilities) if you run low half way to your target you have to plunder a farm to get more which is time comsuming. Also the Longer your on the march the more your men's morale will drop, you'll have to Camp your Armies to keep morale up or plunder villiages wich give you gold.             There is no prisoners of war like later "Total War" titles however if you decimate an army without killing it's leader (Member of enemy royal court) you capture him and can ransom him off let him go or execute him.              The game also gives your Great historical infomation with 3 playable start times all with a diffrent mix of nations to choose from, and a lengthy introduction to each one. To summarize, if your looking for a grand strategy game that is just that, one that you can prepare your armies and plan massive operations, buy this 10 dollar game, you won't regret adding it to your library.

												This is a great game. It's a weird mix of Europa Universalis (real time strategy map, faction events such as rebels) and Total War (tactical battles, faction/location unique units and province improvements). And it works wonderfully.Pros: A quicker yet deeper Total War-like game. The strategic map is real-time, so the game flows better than Total War's turn-based strategic map. It remains manageable because you have a limited set of knights (who can be generals, merchants, priests, etc).Europa Universalis-like events, like rebels, nations rising, crusades. It makes the strategic game really fluid, with factions moving across the map, overextending, and collapsing to rebels or nations rising. Even large nations are not immune, so there isn't an invincible, immovable big blob (except for you if you play things right).Cons: The game is 2D only. While the art style is ok, the low resolution (1024x768) makes playing both the strategy map and tactical battles cumbersome. An HD remake that allows you to zoom out would be awesome. See Majesty HD for reference.Can get repetitive towards the end of the game once you become dominant. AI is a easy once you get over the hump at the start of a new game. AI factions don't often concentrate their forces, and builds way too many low quality units. Even worse, AI alliances don't support each other's armies, which leads to them being defeated separately.

												As a consumer I always try to avoid buying games that will not get play time. It's not fair to the game or my dollar. Because I bought this on sale for a very small amount I was not concerned with the lack of achievements or potential loss. This game was not a loss, it was my addiction for a week. (considering opportunity cost... it may be a loss)This game stood out on the market place because of its Age of Empires II graphics coupled with a seemingly total war "esk" strategy dynamic. Upon reading reviews it had a zealous fanbase. (always a good sign) When this game booted up I was suprised to see that this was published by Paradox Games. That was when I knew, that I would be in for a treat.This game's most valuable asset is the real time mechanic. Most often I avoid real time stategy like the plague because I like to take my time playing turn based stategy games. However, Knights of Honor has a real balanced approach to real time and made a real fresh experience in my primarily turn based game library. With a trade system like Settlers of Catan KoH frees you to focus on the land grab and military aspects of the game. In addition, this game is not so much do or die. Most games I play: Crusader Kings II, Dark Souls II, LoL, require a well planned and finesed approach to everything you do. They will stress you out after a while. The game handles a lot like Sid Meiers Civiliation, its got a relaxed approach that gets only as serious as you want it to be. The last gem within this game is the randomization of the map resources. I cannot tell you how many games are limited by a single game breaking exploit based on an area, character, or strategy. The randomization frees you from the burden of starter placement. It gives you a reason to expand, instead of being passive. It gives the game all the replay value and ultimately drives the game. I would describe this game as Sega's Total War + Settlers of Catan dressed up as Age of Empires II masquerading as Crusader Kings. Very unique.If this game had only received a better name and more marketing it would have been a gaming Giant.

												A good light grand strategy game to get your feet wet in such games. In comparison to Crusader Kings 1/2 and Medieval 2: Total War, it is very arcadey. You can take the known world by pure conquest or by subterfuge using spies, or even by demanding another kingdom recognize your right to certain lands due to to a royal marriage.That said, there is no family tree history. There is just your current ruler (King, Emperor, Sultan, Caliph, Khan, whatever), his wife (either an "ordinary noblewoman" or a woman they married from another kingdom), and their sons and daughters. Only your sons may inherit, you can choose which one becomes king but this can cause some issues. Your daughters can only be married off for royal marriages/alliances.The campaign map is akin to a total war game's campaign map, except in real-time. You can pause or speed up time, however. The battlemap plays out with you actually ordering individual units, and even your marshal (you can not send an army out without a marshal) + his bodyguard, to fight (whether in a field battle or siege). It has the look of a cleaner age of empires 2: the conquerors, in terms of graphics. You may opt to instead let battles auto-resolve (certain marshal traits only apply in auto-resolve). Naval battles are always auto-resolved, and can never be fought manually.The A.I. was purportedly developed simply to entertain the player (it was discussed on the old black sea studios forums), rather than actually challenge them, even on Hard difficulty, but this is more or less the case with pretty much any video game in existence that has functional artificial intelligence, anyway. The game has surprised me a few times, like when I had no heirs to inherit the throne, and it turned out the nobleman whom took the throne for himself (a lord I hired to act as a merchant to earn more gold) was actually a spy for another kingdom... And so he dutifully handed the crown over to said kingdom, and suddenly game over.It still has great entertainment value, however. And there is even a modding community for it, and once you've mastered the game on the "Hard" difficulty setting, there is a "Hard" modification that makes the A.I. into a totally unrepentant warmonger once you've reached a certain amount of provinces, though they can declare war before that point. Moddb.com has some of these modifications.

And it has a weird bug where, when garrisoning troops the mouse gets stuck in its garrisoning task and hindering you to click on most of the stuff. Great... Also the german translation is gone,      -        because of reasons.Playing the actual game brings up mixed feelings. On the one side there is of course nostalgia, the great music, the pretty art style of the game. Also the refreshingly not completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ campaign AI. You can actually form treaties and alliances with them unlike in certain other games. *cough* Also the campaign is in real time just as the battles. Some might not like this, but I enjoy it.On the other side there are the actual battles. Looking back I can't really seem to grasp how I enjoyed them.Here are some points that kill the battles for me:Controlls:  - no way to select multiple troops without drawing a box with the mouse- no way to form a line with multiple troops properlyView:        - no zoom in / zoom out- camera is stuck right on top of the map, so you have absolutely no overviewAI:            - the AI of the troops always tries to attack enemies from the front. This makes sorrounding your enemy and performing hammer and anvil strikes almost impossible.- the troops are able to walk into each other when ordered to attack the same unit.Who needs tactics? Mass wins!General:   - In sieges armies spawn much to close to each other. You have very little time to react to rally your troops as a defender without walls. And as an attacker you need to draw back your troops instantly because they spawn range of the enemies archers and towers.- Stamina is drained too quickly from the troops which makes manouvering in battle difficult and tactics obsolete.- Cavalry is to slow compared to infantry making skirmishing, and using them as a flexible force impossible.And best of all: If your General is killed, the battle is lost automaticaly and you loose all your troops. Which is even more infuriating is the fact, that the enemy general can, and will, ride over and kill your general instantly, winning the battle. Also, if your general and the enemy general are in a fight, the enemy general will win. Always.It happened to me more than once that I was winning the battle and then without noticing (remember the view is stuck right on top of the lawn) the enemy general snuck around my army to kill mine. No call out by the game like: "your general is being attacked!".No, no, we don't need that...Basically you win battles by having better troops, sitting back and letting your archers do most of the work.Well and of course not letting the enemy general kill yours...All in all I'd rather recommend auto resolving them and to concentrade on the campaign.Summary:I can recommend the game for those who like a relaxed and fun campaign, whilst enjoying the beautiful music and art style.But due to the fact that Steam is once again selling a very old game for money without fixing it to work on newer machines I can't.

												This game has a few serious flaws:- no full-screen mode, not even stretched. Horrible.- no zoom-in/out over the map: difficult to estimate the size of a nearby kingdom, difficult to navigate your own kingdom and cities, difficult to get a sense of what is going on- every diplomatic agreement among any other country appears on the notification area, however you receive absolutely *no warning whatsoever* when a kingdom *declares war* on you: if they just immediately on an outpost that has no defensive walls, you are screwed. Now, how does this game qualify as *real time strategy* when it gives you no time to plan and enact a strategy to counter the computer's moves? - apparently, the time can not be paused while still being able to interact with the map to get a better understanding of what is going on in the nearby cities. - the tutorial goes to great distances to explain trivial stuff like 'click here and there to show this and that' - thank you Captain Obvious, I can learn that myself - but it doesn't spend a single word on the most crucial aspects of the game, that is how stats affect other stats. Basically, you've got to do a lot of trial and error the first dozen of matches before you are able to design a sensible strategy and not waste your gold.- at times, armies just sit there doing nothing despite of being given an order repeatedlyPositive aspect- The overall idea of the game is great, but the technical implementation of these ideas is horrific and it is not worth a single penny.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												  Not a terrible game but definitely not a top performer in the genre.  Nice unit choices and a variety of building options.  However the buildings are somewhat weak with their effect and really don't do much for the playability of the game other than give unit recruitment and some resources used for the kingdom advantages part of the game.  The "Royal Court" only consists of 9 slots regardless of how many provinces you own and that gets to be a real problem with expanding your kingdom.  Somehow you have to fit marshals, priests, governors, merchants, spies etc, into these 9 slots to manage your expanding kingdom.  That is pretty much impossible.  I usually went with 1 merchant, 7 marshals and left a spot open for whatever else I needed at any given point which makes the whole kingdom court a useless part of the game.  Even with this strategy it was advance a few provinces and then wait and quell the constant uprisings in the newly conquered provinces.  This takes what seems like forever as you have to wait for the "Nostalgia" effect to drop before the rebels stop spawning in the recently acquired areas.  Diplomacy is unpredictable as nations that you have had good relations with will eventually turn bad for no apparent reason.  Marrying into the noble family of another nation is no guarantee that the nation will have good feelings for you and seems to do nothing but cause problems in the future.  Marrying off a princess is, most of the time, the worst thing you can do.  It doesn't help your standing with the nation your princess is married to and if they claim rights to your lands it goes bad for you either way you decide to handle it.  If you agree, you lose land. If you disagree you lose more than half your kingdom power which effects several aspects of the game to include income, happiness of the populace, and overall standing with other nations. princesses in my kingdoms were all spinsters, never married and an overall waste of the king and queens lustful energy.  There are a lot of things I like about this game. Unfortunately there are a lot of other things I find very undesirable.  Now for the reason I gave this game a "NO" in the recommendation.  With all the little things that are either small irritants or just plainly useless in game play the thing that makes no sense is thus.  I played several campaigns and they all ended the same way.  For no apparent reason or some reason that completely escapes me all of my marshals will just quilt and turn against me.  With population at a content level and everything going well they just decide to turn rebel and start destroying anything and everything around them.  When new marshals are recruited to replace and fight the old ones they too turn rebel and continue the onslaught against their former king.  The developers may as well have just added a message that says: "You have played this particular game enough and even though you have done well and managed your kingdom like a pro, YOU LOSE! please play again soon."  I guess that is one way of getting out of writing a good successful end game screenplay.  If you do decide to purchase this game I'm sure you will get several hours of enjoyment playing it, just don't expect it to be the greatest game of all time because that one hasn't been written yet.  I do wish this game was better than it is.  It had the potential in development but I think they either ran low on funding or just got sloppy towards the end and rushed it out.  Nevertheless I hope you find this helpful and as I said earlier if you do play this I truly hope you find it enjoyable for the parts that do make it fun and take the rest in stride.  Its not a perfect world after all.  Cheers :)

For example Scotland is just two provinces with only one or two trade goods available - if the game were expanded and Scotland were made into more provinces, and more of its RL trade goods implemented in each, then I feel like starting as Scotland and slowly taking over the island would be less annoying.
